title: How to Make Fairy Garden Furniture from Twigs

steps.headline: Cut and glue four 1-inch (2.5-cm) twigs together to make the seat.
steps.description: Use pruning shears to cut four 1-inch (2.5-cm) twigs. make sure that they are straight and all the same thickness. Hot glue the twigs side-by-side to make a square-shaped seat. Make sure that the ends of the twigs are lined up and straight. If there is any unevenness, lightly sand the ends of the twigs with sandpaper. Use twigs that are no thicker than ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm).

steps.headline: Cut two twigs a little longer than your seat for the supports.
steps.description: Measure across the lined up twigs. Add another twig-width to your measurement, then cut two twigs accordingly. The twig-width is simply the width of one twig. If you aren't sure, add about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) to your measurement instead. You don't need a ruler for this. You can just hold a twig against the seat and cut it.

steps.headline: Hot glue the supports across the seat, close to the narrow edges.
steps.description: Make sure that the bottom ends of the supports are flush with the front edge of the seat, and the top ends are extending past the back edge of the seat. Glue the supports about one twig width away from the narrow side edges.

steps.headline: Cut two short twigs and two long twigs for the legs.
steps.description: Make the two front legs about 1 inch (2.5 cm) long. The back legs need to be at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) long as they will also become the back supports. You can make them longer if you want, however. The front legs need to be straight. The back legs can be any shape you want, even curved or forked!

steps.headline: Glue the front legs under the seat to either side of the supports.
steps.description: Place a drop of hot glue on the bottom of the seat and another on the outside edge of the support. Nestle one of the front legs into the glue, making sure that the end is touching the seat, and the side is touching the support. Repeat this step for the other front leg. Glue the front legs as close as possible to the front edge of the seat.

steps.headline: Glue the back legs to the back edge of the seat.
steps.description: Place a drop of hot glue on the outside edge of the extended support, and another drop on the back edge of the seat (not under). Stand the seat up on its front legs, making sure that it is parallel to the ground. Slide the back leg into place. Repeat this step for the other back leg.

steps.headline: Cut and glue 1 to 2 twigs for the backrest.
steps.description: Measure across the back supports, going from the outside edge of one support to the outside edge of the other. Cut a twig according to your measurement, then glue it down to the supports. Repeat this step to add a second backrest just below it, if desired. If your back supports are forked, you can skip the backrest.

steps.headline: Decorate the seat, as desired.
steps.description: Place a tuft of soft, squishy moss onto the seat to use as a cushion. To make the chair fancier, decorate it with clear, faceted glass or plastic beads (iridescent ones would be especially pretty). Twist some gold or copper wire around the back rest, and slip more beads onto it!

steps.headline: Saw a thin disk from a thick branch to make the table top.
steps.description: Choose a branch that is about 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) thick. You will need to saw off the end of the branch first so that the table is nice and smooth. Next, use a hacksaw or a table saw to cut a 1⁄4 to 1⁄2-inch (0.64 to 1.27-cm) thick disk. Make marks on the branch with pen or pencil where you need to cut first. Hold the branch steady against a flat surface while cutting. You can also use a pre-cut disk of wood from the arts and crafts store, but it may be too big. A large, wooden button may also work if you don't mind the thread holes.

steps.headline: Use pruning shears to cut three twigs for the legs.
steps.description: Make the twigs about 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) long. Cutting three legs instead of four means that your table will be more stable and less likely to wobble, especially if the legs or ground are uneven.

steps.headline: Drill three holes into the disk, if you want a stronger table.
steps.description: These holes will be for the table legs, so make sure that they are wide enough. Space the holes evenly in a triangular formation. If you can, drill the holes at an angle pointing towards the center of the table.

steps.headline: Place a drop of glue into each hole.
steps.description: You can use hot glue, tacky glue, or wood glue. If you use hot glue, be prepared to work quickly as it sets up fast. If you didn't make the holes, place three drops of glue on the flat side of the disk in a triangular formation.

steps.headline: Insert each twig into the glue.
steps.description: If you used tacky glue or wood glue, you may have to place something around the legs to support them. Little mounds of clay will work great for this, but you can also use pebbles or little pieces of wood.

steps.headline: Turn the table right side up and decorate it as desired.
steps.description: Find a spot in your fairy garden and set it down. Add some acorn cap tea cups and leaf plates. You can even make a mini floral arrangement using seed pods, large beads, and tiny flowers.

steps.headline: Cut and glue 6 to 8 twigs together to make the base of your bed.
steps.description: Use pruning shears to cut 6 to 8 twigs. Hot glue the twigs side-by-side to make a rectangle, making sure that the narrow ends are even. If they are jagged, you can leave them as-is for a rustic touch, or sand them down for a nicer finish. How long you cut the twigs is up to you. Something between 3 to 4 inches (7.6 to 10.2 cm) would be ideal, however.

steps.headline: Cut four twigs for the bed posts.
steps.description: Something between 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) would work great. You can make all four bed posts the same length, or you can make the one set longer than the other set.

steps.headline: Hot glue the bed posts to the narrow edges of the bed.
steps.description: Place a bead of hot glue on the narrow edge of the rectangle, right next to a corner. Press a twig into the glue, leaving about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) of twig beneath the bed base. Repeat this step for all four legs. If you made your twigs different lengths, use the shorter ones for the foot of the bed, and the longer ones for the head.

steps.headline: Make a headboard using two twigs, if desired.
steps.description: Measure across the two bedposts on the head of your bead. Cut two twigs according to your measurement, then hot glue them down across the posts. Place one twig closer to the top, and the other twig closer to the bed base. Hot glue a pretty bead to the top of each bed post. A clear, faceted, plastic or glass bead would look lovely!

steps.headline: Make some bedding using moss and fabric.
steps.description: Set a large tuft of moss on top of the bed. Cut a square out of pretty fabric, and drape it over the bed for the blanket. Add a smaller ball of moss, preferably in a different color, for the pillow.

text: Making a Chair Cut and glue four 1-inch (2.5-cm) twigs together to make the seat. Use pruning shears to cut four 1-inch (2.5-cm) twigs. make sure that they are straight and all the same thickness. Hot glue the twigs side-by-side to make a square-shaped seat. Make sure that the ends of the twigs are lined up and straight. If there is any unevenness, lightly sand the ends of the twigs with sandpaper. Use twigs that are no thicker than ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm). Cut two twigs a little longer than your seat for the supports. Measure across the lined up twigs. Add another twig-width to your measurement, then cut two twigs accordingly. The twig-width is simply the width of one twig. If you aren't sure, add about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) to your measurement instead. You don't need a ruler for this. You can just hold a twig against the seat and cut it. Hot glue the supports across the seat, close to the narrow edges. Make sure that the bottom ends of the supports are flush with the front edge of the seat, and the top ends are extending past the back edge of the seat. Glue the supports about one twig width away from the narrow side edges. Cut two short twigs and two long twigs for the legs. Make the two front legs about 1 inch (2.5 cm) long. The back legs need to be at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) long as they will also become the back supports. You can make them longer if you want, however. The front legs need to be straight. The back legs can be any shape you want, even curved or forked! Glue the front legs under the seat to either side of the supports. Place a drop of hot glue on the bottom of the seat and another on the outside edge of the support. Nestle one of the front legs into the glue, making sure that the end is touching the seat, and the side is touching the support. Repeat this step for the other front leg. Glue the front legs as close as possible to the front edge of the seat. Glue the back legs to the back edge of the seat. Place a drop of hot glue on the outside edge of the extended support, and another drop on the back edge of the seat (not under). Stand the seat up on its front legs, making sure that it is parallel to the ground. Slide the back leg into place. Repeat this step for the other back leg. Cut and glue 1 to 2 twigs for the backrest. Measure across the back supports, going from the outside edge of one support to the outside edge of the other. Cut a twig according to your measurement, then glue it down to the supports. Repeat this step to add a second backrest just below it, if desired. If your back supports are forked, you can skip the backrest. Decorate the seat, as desired. Place a tuft of soft, squishy moss onto the seat to use as a cushion. To make the chair fancier, decorate it with clear, faceted glass or plastic beads (iridescent ones would be especially pretty). Twist some gold or copper wire around the back rest, and slip more beads onto it! Making a Table Saw a thin disk from a thick branch to make the table top. Choose a branch that is about 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) thick. You will need to saw off the end of the branch first so that the table is nice and smooth. Next, use a hacksaw or a table saw to cut a 1⁄4 to 1⁄2-inch (0.64 to 1.27-cm) thick disk. Make marks on the branch with pen or pencil where you need to cut first. Hold the branch steady against a flat surface while cutting. You can also use a pre-cut disk of wood from the arts and crafts store, but it may be too big. A large, wooden button may also work if you don't mind the thread holes. Use pruning shears to cut three twigs for the legs. Make the twigs about 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) long. Cutting three legs instead of four means that your table will be more stable and less likely to wobble, especially if the legs or ground are uneven. Drill three holes into the disk, if you want a stronger table. These holes will be for the table legs, so make sure that they are wide enough. Space the holes evenly in a triangular formation. If you can, drill the holes at an angle pointing towards the center of the table. Place a drop of glue into each hole. You can use hot glue, tacky glue, or wood glue. If you use hot glue, be prepared to work quickly as it sets up fast. If you didn't make the holes, place three drops of glue on the flat side of the disk in a triangular formation. Insert each twig into the glue. If you used tacky glue or wood glue, you may have to place something around the legs to support them. Little mounds of clay will work great for this, but you can also use pebbles or little pieces of wood. Turn the table right side up and decorate it as desired. Find a spot in your fairy garden and set it down. Add some acorn cap tea cups and leaf plates. You can even make a mini floral arrangement using seed pods, large beads, and tiny flowers. Making a Bed Cut and glue 6 to 8 twigs together to make the base of your bed. Use pruning shears to cut 6 to 8 twigs. Hot glue the twigs side-by-side to make a rectangle, making sure that the narrow ends are even. If they are jagged, you can leave them as-is for a rustic touch, or sand them down for a nicer finish. How long you cut the twigs is up to you. Something between 3 to 4 inches (7.6 to 10.2 cm) would be ideal, however. Cut four twigs for the bed posts. Something between 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) would work great. You can make all four bed posts the same length, or you can make the one set longer than the other set. Hot glue the bed posts to the narrow edges of the bed. Place a bead of hot glue on the narrow edge of the rectangle, right next to a corner. Press a twig into the glue, leaving about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) of twig beneath the bed base. Repeat this step for all four legs. If you made your twigs different lengths, use the shorter ones for the foot of the bed, and the longer ones for the head. Make a headboard using two twigs, if desired. Measure across the two bedposts on the head of your bead. Cut two twigs according to your measurement, then hot glue them down across the posts. Place one twig closer to the top, and the other twig closer to the bed base. Hot glue a pretty bead to the top of each bed post. A clear, faceted, plastic or glass bead would look lovely! Make some bedding using moss and fabric. Set a large tuft of moss on top of the bed. Cut a square out of pretty fabric, and drape it over the bed for the blanket. Add a smaller ball of moss, preferably in a different color, for the pillow.
sentences: Making a Chair Cut and glue four 1-inch (2.5-cm) twigs together to make the seat.
Use pruning shears to cut four 1-inch (2.5-cm) twigs.
make sure that they are straight and all the same thickness.
Hot glue the twigs side-by-side to make a square-shaped seat.
Make sure that the ends of the twigs are lined up and straight.
If there is any unevenness, lightly sand the ends of the twigs with sandpaper.
Use twigs that are no thicker than ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm).
Cut two twigs a little longer than your seat for the supports.
Measure across the lined up twigs.
Add another twig-width to your measurement, then cut two twigs accordingly.
The twig-width is simply the width of one twig.
If you aren't sure, add about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) to your measurement instead.
You don't need a ruler for this.
You can just hold a twig against the seat and cut it.
Hot glue the supports across the seat, close to the narrow edges.
Make sure that the bottom ends of the supports are flush with the front edge of the seat, and the top ends are extending past the back edge of the seat.
Glue the supports about one twig width away from the narrow side edges.
Cut two short twigs and two long twigs for the legs.
Make the two front legs about 1 inch (2.5 cm) long.
The back legs need to be at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) long as they will also become the back supports.
You can make them longer if you want, however.
The front legs need to be straight.
The back legs can be any shape you want, even curved or forked!
Glue the front legs under the seat to either side of the supports.
Place a drop of hot glue on the bottom of the seat and another on the outside edge of the support.
Nestle one of the front legs into the glue, making sure that the end is touching the seat, and the side is touching the support.
Repeat this step for the other front leg.
Glue the front legs as close as possible to the front edge of the seat.
Glue the back legs to the back edge of the seat.
Place a drop of hot glue on the outside edge of the extended support, and another drop on the back edge of the seat (not under).
Stand the seat up on its front legs, making sure that it is parallel to the ground.
Slide the back leg into place.
Repeat this step for the other back leg.
Cut and glue 1 to 2 twigs for the backrest.
Measure across the back supports, going from the outside edge of one support to the outside edge of the other.
Cut a twig according to your measurement, then glue it down to the supports.
Repeat this step to add a second backrest just below it, if desired.
If your back supports are forked, you can skip the backrest.
Decorate the seat, as desired.
Place a tuft of soft, squishy moss onto the seat to use as a cushion.
To make the chair fancier, decorate it with clear, faceted glass or plastic beads (iridescent ones would be especially pretty).
Twist some gold or copper wire around the back rest, and slip more beads onto it!
Making a Table Saw a thin disk from a thick branch to make the table top.
Choose a branch that is about 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) thick.
You will need to saw off the end of the branch first so that the table is nice and smooth.
Next, use a hacksaw or a table saw to cut a 1⁄4 to 1⁄2-inch (0.64 to 1.27-cm) thick disk.
Make marks on the branch with pen or pencil where you need to cut first.
Hold the branch steady against a flat surface while cutting.
You can also use a pre-cut disk of wood from the arts and crafts store, but it may be too big.
A large, wooden button may also work if you don't mind the thread holes.
Use pruning shears to cut three twigs for the legs.
Make the twigs about 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) long.
Cutting three legs instead of four means that your table will be more stable and less likely to wobble, especially if the legs or ground are uneven.
Drill three holes into the disk, if you want a stronger table.
These holes will be for the table legs, so make sure that they are wide enough.
Space the holes evenly in a triangular formation.
If you can, drill the holes at an angle pointing towards the center of the table.
Place a drop of glue into each hole.
You can use hot glue, tacky glue, or wood glue.
If you use hot glue, be prepared to work quickly as it sets up fast.
If you didn't make the holes, place three drops of glue on the flat side of the disk in a triangular formation.
Insert each twig into the glue.
If you used tacky glue or wood glue, you may have to place something around the legs to support them.
Little mounds of clay will work great for this, but you can also use pebbles or little pieces of wood.
Turn the table right side up and decorate it as desired.
Find a spot in your fairy garden and set it down.
Add some acorn cap tea cups and leaf plates.
You can even make a mini floral arrangement using seed pods, large beads, and tiny flowers.
Making a Bed Cut and glue 6 to 8 twigs together to make the base of your bed.
Use pruning shears to cut 6 to 8 twigs.
Hot glue the twigs side-by-side to make a rectangle, making sure that the narrow ends are even.
If they are jagged, you can leave them as-is for a rustic touch, or sand them down for a nicer finish.
How long you cut the twigs is up to you.
Something between 3 to 4 inches (7.6 to 10.2 cm) would be ideal, however.
Cut four twigs for the bed posts.
Something between 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) would work great.
You can make all four bed posts the same length, or you can make the one set longer than the other set.
Hot glue the bed posts to the narrow edges of the bed.
Place a bead of hot glue on the narrow edge of the rectangle, right next to a corner.
Press a twig into the glue, leaving about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) of twig beneath the bed base.
Repeat this step for all four legs.
If you made your twigs different lengths, use the shorter ones for the foot of the bed, and the longer ones for the head.
Make a headboard using two twigs, if desired.
Measure across the two bedposts on the head of your bead.
Cut two twigs according to your measurement, then hot glue them down across the posts.
Place one twig closer to the top, and the other twig closer to the bed base.
Hot glue a pretty bead to the top of each bed post.
A clear, faceted, plastic or glass bead would look lovely!
Make some bedding using moss and fabric.
Set a large tuft of moss on top of the bed.
Cut a square out of pretty fabric, and drape it over the bed for the blanket.
Add a smaller ball of moss, preferably in a different color, for the pillow.
